details.title: Circular Layout Cutsets: An Approach for Improving Consecutive Cutset Bounds for Network Reliability

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Comput. Sci., Alberta Univ., Edmonton, Alta.

p: Ehab S. Elmallah received the B.Sc. (1978) in computer science and automatic control from the University of Alexandria, the M.Sc. (1984) in computing science from the University of Saskatchewan, and the Ph.D. (1987) in computer science from the University of Waterloo. He is currently an Associate Professor at the Department of Computing Science, at the University of Alberta. His research interests lie in the application of combinatorial and probabilistic methods in network design, and performance evaluation, with a particular emphasis on resource management problems in wireless cellular networks, sensor networks, and ad hoc networks. His research is supported by grants from NSERC, CITR, and CITO. He serves on the organizing and program committees of numerous international conferences on communications, and computer networks. He is a member of the IEEE, and the Institute of Combinatorics and its Applications.

(1977) in electrical engineering from Ain-Shams University in Cairo; and the M.Math (1984), and Ph.D. (1989) in computer science from the University of Waterloo, Ontario. He is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at Kuwait University. His interests include computer networks, network reliability, distributed systems and databases, and design of algorithms.

details.abstract: In this paper, we introduce a new type of parameterized class of cutsets for the 2-terminal network reliability problem, called the circular layout (CL) cutsets with parameter k, and devise a polynomial time algorithm for computing upper bounds from such structures. The CL cutsets, and the devised bounding method are characterized by the following aspects. 1) CL cutsets include the well known class of consecutive minimal cutsets, introduced by Shanthikumar, as a proper subset. Thus, bounds obtained by our main algorithm yield strict improvements on the basic consecutive cutsets algorithm. We note that extensive empirical studies done to date have shown that the consecutive cutsets method, when empowered by heuristics for choosing suitable cutsets, yields competitive bounds. 2) CL cutsets satisfy the semilattice structure required by Shier's algorithm for computing upper bounds in time polynomial in the number of cuts in a given cutset. Thus, CL cutsets define a new class of efficiently constructible cutsets of polynomial size that benefit from such generalized algorithm. 3) For any fixed value of the parameter k, the devised bounding method can be adapted to satisfy stringent constant-time update constraints, required by the most probable state algorithm of Colbourn & Harms , for obtaining iteratively improvable bounds, without adding significant time overhead to the method. Moreover, the devised bounding algorithm is easy to implement, and the obtained numerical results show more than a 32% improvement over bounds obtained by the basic consecutive cutsets algorithm

context.text: For the third direction, the work of [8], [12], [29], [30], and some of the references therein, have amply considered the development of iteratively improvable bounding methods based on the idea of generating the most probable states of a given stochastic network.

In [8] & [29], however, particular consideration is given to developing sufficient conditions under which any auxiliary bounding algorithm can be used to improve the time-accuracy characteristics of a most probable states method; the developed conditions impose stringent timing requirements (referred to also as constant-time update constraints) that should be satisfied by the auxiliary bounding method so as to have a small effect on the time per iteration of the method.
Using a specially developed dynamic program, the results of [8] show (among other results) that the consecutive cuts bound can be adapted to satisfy the required constant-time update constraints.

The extensive numerical results obtained in [8] & [29] indicate that utilizing nontrivial auxiliary bounding algorithms within the general framework of a most-probable-states method can sometimes result in dramatic improvements over results obtained without using such algorithms.

From the above overview, we remark that the family of consecutive cuts is distinguished in that it satisfies both the semilattice conditions of [24], and for which a bounding method exists that satisfies the constant-time update constraints of [8], thus, encouraging further research to obtain larger classes of cuts that maintain both of the two latter properties.
In addition, we show a somewhat surprising result: despite the nontrivial structure of the algorithm, it can be adapted to satisfy the constant-time update constraints of [8].

As alluded to in Section I, a strongly desirable feature of any such bounding algorithm is its suitability for use in improving the time-accuracy characteristics of a most probable states bounding method, as amply discussed in [8].

context.text: As noted in [11] & [29], for the special case of the 2-terminal problem, any set of edge-disjoint cuts, or noncrossing cuts, satisfies the consecutive cuts property.
To remedy the problem, Harms (see [11], and the references therein) devised several selection heuristics that yield competitive bounds when combined with Shanthikumar's dynamic program.

Extensive testing for many upper bounding techniques appears also in [11]; the results show that the consecutive-cuts bound provides practical strength, although it is not the strongest in all available bounds for low values of \$p\$ (e.g., \$p< 0.25\$).

As noted in [11], any sequence of \$n-1\$ consecutive minimal cuts in an \$n\$-vertex network can be described by a permutation \$\pi=\{\pi_{1},\pi_{2},\ldots,\pi_{n}\}\$ of the vertices, where \$\pi_{1}=s\$, \$\pi_{n}=t\$; and the \$i\$th cut \$C_{i}\$ consists of all edges \$(x,y)\$, where \$x\in\{\pi_{1},\ldots,\pi_{i}\}\$, and \$y\in\{\pi_{i+1},\ldots,\pi_{n}\}\$ (see, e.g., Fig. 1).

context.text: For the second direction, Provan & Ball [18] have shown a remarkable result: the exact \$Rel(s,t)\$ value (for undirected or directed networks) can be computed in time which is polynomial in the number of minimal \$(s,t)\$-cuts of the underlying network.

In contrast, for directed networks, [18] shows that no general algorithm for computing the exact \$Rel(s,t)\$ in time polynomial in the number of pathsets of the given graph can exist unless \$P=NP\$.

Subsequently, Shier [24] extended the algorithm of [18] by devising a dynamic program for computing an upper bound from any given cutset that satisfies a certain semilattice structure;3
3A set \${\cal C}=\{C_{1},C_{2},\ldots,C_{n}\}\$ of \$(s,t)\$–cuts satisfies the semilattice structure of [24] if there exists a partial order, denoted \$\preceq\$, on \${\cal C}\$ such that: (a) any two elements \$C_{i}\$ and \$C_{j}\$ have a unique greatest lower bound element, denoted \$C_{i}\wedge C_{j}\$, where \$C_{i}\wedge C_{j}\subseteq C_{i}\bigcup C_{j}\$, and (b) if \$C_{i}\preceq C_{k}\preceq C_{j}\$, and edge \$e\in C_{i}\bigcap C_{j}\$ then \$e\in C_{k}\$ the dynamic program runs in time polynomial in the size of the given cutset (a similar result holds for computing lower bounds from pathsets); [24] has also shown that the family of consecutive cuts satisfies the stated conditions of the semilattice structure.

In [8] & [29], however, particular consideration is given to developing sufficient conditions under which any auxiliary bounding algorithm can be used to improve the time-accuracy characteristics of a most probable states method; the developed conditions impose stringent timing requirements (referred to also as constant-time update constraints) that should be satisfied by the auxiliary bounding method so as to have a small effect on the time per iteration of the method.
